questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended temperature for drugs which need to be stored in a refrigerator but not in the freezer ?
Which statement regarding pharmacokinetics is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The volume of distribution (Vd) is a measure of drug distribution in the body

options.label: B
options.text: Clearance (Cl) represents the rate at which a drug is eliminated from the body

options.label: C
options.text: Bioavailability (F) is the fraction of an administered dose that reaches systemic circulation unchanged

options.label: D
options.text: The half-life (T1/2) is unaffected by liver metabolism

questions.correct_answer: D. The half-life (T1/2) is unaffected by liver metabolism

questions.text: A patient with asthma is prescribed a bronchodilator to help manage their symptoms. The drug works by activating β2-adrenergic receptors in the airways, causing smooth muscle relaxation and bronchodilation. However, the patient also has hypertension and is taking a β-blocker medication to lower their blood pressure. In this scenario, what is the relationship between the bronchodilator (β2-agonist) and the β-blocker?

options.label: A
options.text: The β-blocker is a competitive antagonist of the β2-agonist.

options.label: B
options.text: The β-blocker is a non-competitive antagonist of the β2-agonist.

options.label: C
options.text: The β-blocker is a physiological antagonist of the β2-agonist.

options.label: D
options.text: The β-blocker is an inverse agonist of the β2-agonist.

questions.correct_answer: A. The β-blocker is a competitive antagonist of the β2-agonist.
questions.explanation:
Type of Antagonist

Description

Mechanism

Example

Competitive Antagonist

(Option A)

Competes with agonists for the same binding site, reducing the potency of the agonist.

Reversible binding to the same receptor site as the agonist.

Propranolol (β-blocker) binds to β-adrenergic receptors, reducing the effect of adrenaline

Non-Competitive Antagonist

(Option B)

Prevents the action of an agonist without competing with it for the binding site.

Irreversible binding to the receptor reduces the maximum effect of the agonist.

Phenoxybenzamine binds to α-adrenergic receptors, reducing the effect of adrenaline.

Physiological Antagonist

(Option C)

Acts on different receptors or mechanisms to produce opposite effects on the same physiological function.

Does not directly interact with the same receptor or signaling pathway as the agonist.

Calcium channel blocker reduces the effect of adrenaline on the heart.

Inverse Agonist

(Option D)

Selectively binds to the inactive conformation of a constitutively active receptor, reducing the basal activity of the receptor.

Binds to the inactive conformation of the receptor, reducing the basal activity.

Propranolol (β-blocker) can act as an inverse agonist on β-adrenergic receptors, reducing the basal activity of the receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Done when the clinical response can be easily measured

options.label: B
options.text: Done for wide therapeutic index drugs

options.label: C
options.text: Atenolol is an example of a drug for which TDM is required

options.label: D
options.text: TDM can be done if the drug has erratic pharmacokinetics

questions.correct_answer: D. TDM can be done if the drug has erratic pharmacokinetics
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Definition

Systematic measurement of drug concentrations in plasma to optimise therapy.

Purpose
  • To ensure therapeutic drug levels are achieved
  • To confirm poisoning
  • To check compliance

Situations

requiring TDM
  • Drugs with erratic pharmacokinetics and low safety margins (e.g., digoxin, anticonvulsants, antiarrhythmics, theophylline, aminoglycoside antibiotics, lithium, tricyclic antidepressants)
  • High individual variability (e.g., antidepressants, lithium)
  • Toxic drugs in renal failure (e.g., aminoglycosides, vancomycin)
  • Cases of poisoning
  • Unexplained therapeutic failure (e.g., antimicrobials)
  • Patient compliance monitoring (e.g., psychotropic drugs) 

Drugs Not Requiring TDM
  • Drugs with easily measurable responses (e.g., antihypertensives, hypoglycaemics, diuretics, oral anticoagulants, inhalational general anaesthetics) (Option A and C ruled out)
  • Drugs that are activated in the body (e.g., levodopa)
  • 'Hit and run' drugs with prolonged effects (e.g., MAO inhibitors, reserpine, guanethidine, omeprazole)
  • Drugs with irreversible actions (e.g., organophosphates, phenoxybenzamine)

questions.text: A diabetic patient on regular insulin therapy accidentally injects himself with a higher dose than prescribed. He experiences sweating, trembling, confusion, and dizziness. Which type of adverse drug reaction (ADR) can be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of reaction

Description

Example

Augmented

Dose-dependent, predictable, and more common.

↑ Insulin → hypoglycemia.

Bizzare

Dose-independent, non-predictable, less common, and more serious.

Allergy & idiosyncracy.

Chronic

Dose & duration dependent

Suppression of hypothalamic-pituitary axis by chronic steroid use.

Delayed

Duration dependent

Kidney disease from long-term NSAID use.

End of use

Withdrawal symptoms

Opioid withdrawal.

Failure

Failure of therapy

Enzyme inducers → OCP failure.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Placebo drugs except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is used as a dummy medication

questions.correct_answer: B. It contains the active moiety

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman comes to the antenatal clinic for regular check up. An ultrasound of her abdomen showed craniofacial abnormalities, hypoplasia of the phalanges, and cleft palate. Which of the following medications is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Teratogenic Disorder

Acitretin

Craniofacial anomalies, heart defects, CNS malformations.

Alcohol

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (growth retardation, facial anomalies, CNS dysfunction, ASD, VSD).

ACE inhibitors & Angiotensin-receptor blockers

Renal dysgenesis, oligohydramnios, lung hypoplasia, skull hypoplasia.

Carbamazepine

Neural tube defects (spina bifida), craniofacial defects.

Isotretinoin (Option B)

Craniofacial anomalies, heart defects, CNS malformations.

Lithium

Ebstein's anomaly (tricuspid valve malformation).

Thalidomide

Severe limb defects (phocomelia), ear, cardiac, and genitourinary malformations.

Carbimazole & methimazole

Choanal atresia, aplasia cutis, and fetal goitre.

Penicillamine

Cutis laxa syndrome.

Statins

Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheo-oesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, and limb defects (VACTERAL defects).

SSRIs

Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn.

Valproic acid (Option A)

Neural tube defects (spina bifida), craniofacial defects, cardiovascular malformations, and developmental delay.

Warfarin (Option D)

Fetal warfarin syndrome: Nasal hypoplasia, stippled epiphyses, limb hypoplasia, and central nervous system abnormalities.

questions.text: A drug given to a patient is known to follow a capacity-limited elimination pattern. Which of the following is incorrect about this mode of drug elimination?

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of the drug eliminated per unit of time will remain constant

options.label: B
options.text: Clearance of the drug will be less at higher concentrations.

options.label: C
options.text: The half-life of the drug will be longer at lower concentrations

options.label: D
options.text: The rate of elimination of the drug is independent of plasma concentration.

questions.correct_answer: C. The half-life of the drug will be longer at lower concentrations
questions.explanation:
First-order kinetics

Zero-order kinetics

Description

A constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit of time.

A constant amount of the drug is eliminated per unit of time.

Rate of clearance

Constant

More at lower concentrations and less at higher concentrations.

Half-life

Constant

Less at lower concentrations and more at higher concentrations.

Rate of elimination

Proportional to its plasma concentration.

Independent of plasma concentration.

Examples

Most of the drugs.

Alcohol, aspirin, theophylline, tolbutamide, and warfarin.

questions.text: A 70 kg patient is administered 2 mg of warfarin. If its plasma concentration is 200 mcg/L, calculate the apparent volume of distribution of the drug.
questions.explanation:
Vd = Dose of drug administered/plasma concentration

Low Vd

High Vd

A larger portion of a drug is in the intravascular compartment.

A larger portion of a drug is in the extravascular compartment.

It is easily removed by haemodialysis.

It can be difficult to remove by haemodialysis.

Factors responsible:

  • Extensive plasma protein binding
  • Hydrophilic nature

Factors responsible:

  • Extensive body tissue binding
  • Lipophilic nature

Examples: warfarin, diclofenac

Examples: Digoxin, propranolol, morphine

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing treatment for latent tuberculosis with a standard regimen. After a few weeks of therapy, he develops peripheral neuropathy. His doctor explains that this side effect is related to the metabolism of isoniazid. Which type of phase II metabolism is responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Fast Acetylators

Slow Acetylators

NAT2 enzyme activity

High

Low

Drug concentrations

Low

High

Increased risk for
  • Reduced microbial cure.
  • Increased relapse.
  • Acquired drug resistance.
  • Hepatotoxicity.
  • Peripheral neuropathy/neuritis.

questions.text: Match the following CYP450 enzymes with the drugs they primarily metabolise: CYP450 Enzyme Drug 1. CYP1A2 A. Phenytoin 2. CYP2C9 B. Midazolam 3. CYP2C19 C. Clopazine 4. CYP2D6 D. Pantoprazole 5. CYP3A4 E. Codeine
questions.explanation:
CYP Enzymes

Substrates/Drugs

CYP1A2
  • Theophylline
  • Clozapine

CYP2C9 (earlier CYP2C8)

(Saturation kinetics is seen)
  • Phenytoin
  • Warfarin

CYP2C19
  • Clopidogrel (see note below)
  • Azoles: Voriconazole, Ketoconazole
  • PPI: Omeprazole, Pantoprazole

CYP2D6
  • Propranolol
  • Quinidine
  • Tamoxifen
  • TCA
  • SSRIs
  • Opioids (Codeine)
  • Antipsychotics (all except clozapine)

CYP2E1
  • Paracetamol

CYP3A4
  • Astemizole
  • Midazolam
  • Cyclosporine/Tacrolimus
  • Diltiazem/ verapamil
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Fexofenadine/Terfenadine

questions.text: All of the following are phase 1 reactions except?
questions.explanation:
Phase 1

(Exposes Functional group on Drug)

Phase 2

(Makes drug Water Soluble)

The activity of the drug

Drugs convert into active & inactive forms.
  • The drug converts into active form only, except morphine & minoxidil.
  • Enzymes transfer polar groups.

Types of reaction and their site

Microsomal reactions:

  • Oxidation (Most Common) & Reduction (mediated by CYP450 enzymes).
  • Hydrolysis.
  • Deamination.
  • Dehydrogenation.
  • Cyclisation.
  • Decyclisation (Options A, B and D ruled out).
  • Microsomal reaction:
    • Glucuronide conjugation.
  • Non-microsomal reactions:
    • Acetylation.
    • Methylation.
    • Sulfation.
    • Glycination.
    • Glutathionation.
    • Ribonucleoside/nucleotide synthesis.

M/C reaction

Oxidation & reduction.

Glucuronide conjugation.

questions.text: In drug mechanisms observed in cancer cells, which of the following accurately describes the role of the P-glycoprotein pump (Pgp)?

options.label: A
options.text: Pgp facilitates drug uptake into tumour cells

options.label: B
options.text: Pgp reduces drug elimination from tumour cells

options.label: C
options.text: Pgp is involved in drug efflux from tumour cells

options.label: D
options.text: Pgp has no significant impact on drug transport within tumour cells

questions.correct_answer: C. Pgp is involved in drug efflux from tumour cells
questions.explanation:
P-glycoprotein Inducer

P-glycoprotein Inhibitor

Activity

Increases the activity of Pgp

Decreases the activity of Pgp

Drugs
  • Rifampicin.
  • Phenobarbitone.

Mnemonic: QVACKER

  • Quinidine
  • Verapamil
  • Amiodarone
  • Clarithromycin
  • Ketoconazole
  • Erythromycin
  • Ritonavir

Combined with Substrate

of p-glycoprotein

(Digoxin)

Increases the activity of P-gp.

  • Increased urinary excretion.
  • Digoxin is excreted.

Reduces the activity of P-gp.

  • Reduced urinary excretion.
  • Increased plasma concentration of the drug.
  • Toxicity of digoxin: Arrhythmias.

questions.text: Which statement is not true about intracellular receptors?

options.label: A
options.text: Intracytoplasmic receptors are attached to heat shock proteins (HSP) when inactive.

options.label: B
options.text: Intracellular receptors interact with lipid-soluble ligands that can pass through the cell membrane.

options.label: C
options.text: Intracellular receptors typically require second messengers to relay the signal inside the cell.

options.label: D
options.text: They interact with co-activators or co-repressors in the nucleus

questions.correct_answer: C. Intracellular receptors typically require second messengers to relay the signal inside the cell.

Intracytoplasmic Receptors

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of epilepsy presents for a medication review. He has been taking phenytoin for the past year and wants to ensure his medication dosage is appropriate. Which of the following is the therapeutic range of phenytoin?
Which of the following statements is true about dose-response curves (DRCs)?

options.label: A
options.text: Graded DRCs measure the all-or-none response to different drug doses within a population.

options.label: B
options.text: Quantal DRCs plot the response to a drug continuously within an individual.

options.label: C
options.text: U-shaped DRCs are rare and can indicate toxicity at both low and high doses.

options.label: D
options.text: Graded DRCs are used to calculate the median effective dose (ED50) and the median lethal dose (LD50) in a population.

questions.correct_answer: C. U-shaped DRCs are rare and can indicate toxicity at both low and high doses.
questions.explanation:
Drug /hormone/vitamin

Deficiency

Excess

Insulin

Diabetes

Hypoglycemia

Iron

Anemia

Hemochromatosis

Vitamin A

Night blindness

Liver damage, blurred vision.

questions.text: A clinical trial of 4 new drugs was conducted, and the following graphs were obtained. Based on these graphs, which of the following statements is/are correct? a) Drug A has the highest efficacy as well as the highest potency. b) Drug A has the highest efficacy but the lowest potency. c) Drug D has the highest efficacy as well as the highest potency. d) Drug B is more potent than drug C.

options.label: A
options.text: Statements a and d are correct

options.label: B
options.text: Statements b and d are correct

options.label: D
options.text: None of the statements are correct

questions.correct_answer: A. Statements a and d are correct

questions.text: Identify the correct statement based on the following Michaelis-Menten graph showing the effect of different types of inhibitors on a reaction.

options.label: C
options.text: Vmax is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration

questions.explanation:
COMPETITIVE INHIBITOR

NON-COMPETITIVE INHIBITOR

Uncompetitive inhibitior

Substrate resemblance

Resembles substrate.

It does not resemble the substrate.

It does not resemble the substrate.

Effect on increasing [S]

Inhibition can be reversed.

Inhibition cannot be reversed.

Inhibition can be reversed.

Binding site

Active site.

Allosteric site.

Enzyme substrate complex

Vmax

Unchanged. (Option A)

Decreases (as active enzyme decreases). (Option B)

Decreases (as active enzyme decreases).

Km

Increases (more substrate needed to overcome inhibited enzyme).

Unchanged (increasing substrate does not overcome the inhibition).

Increases (more substrate needed to overcome inhibited enzyme).

questions.text: Which of the following agents inhibits the action of an agonist on a receptor or the subsequent response but does not have any effect of its own?
questions.explanation:
Drug C (Option C): Antagonist


 
  • It prevents the action of an agonist on a receptor or the subsequent response but does not have any effect of its own. 
  • Naloxone, an opioid receptor antagonist, is commonly used to reverse opioid overdose.

Drug A (Option A): Agonist

 
  • It activates a receptor to produce an effect similar to the physiological signal molecule (e.g., morphine at opioid receptors).

Drug D (Option D): Inverse Agonist


 
  • It activates a receptor to produce an effect opposite to that of an agonist (e.g., Rimonabant at cannabinoid receptors).

Drug B (Option B): Partial Agonist
  • It activates a receptor to produce a submaximal effect and can block the action of a full agonist (e.g., Buprenorphine at opioid receptors).

Super Agonist
  • Not directly relevant to opioid overdose treatment but produces a maximum response greater than that of the endogenous agonist (e.g., BMS-986121 at GLP-1 receptors).

questions.text: Match the phases of drug trials with their correct descriptions: Phase Description 1. Phase 0 a. Determines drug efficacy and side effects on a heterogeneous population 2. Phase 1 b. Monitor long-term side effects and drug interaction in hidden populations. 3. Phase 2 c. Human testing to assess drug safety and maximum tolerable dose (MDT). 4. Phase 3 d. Randomized trials to assess drug efficacy and optimal dosing 5. Phase 4 e: Low dosing trials to check drug-target binding.
questions.explanation:
Phases

Description

Phase 0
  • Design: An open-label trial
  • Purpose: 
    • Check the target binding of a drug
    • Check the pharmacokinetics of the drug
  • Called a micro-dosing trial (100 micrograms dose)
  • Non-mandatory clinical trial

Phase 1
  • Design: An open-label trial
  • Purpose: 
    • Evaluate drug safety- the most important
    • Evaluate MTD (maximum tolerable dose), loading dose and drug half-life.
    • Evaluate drug pharmacokinetics (absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion)
  • Called the first human trial 

Phase 2
  • Design: Randomized clinical trial (RCT)
  • Purpose: 
    • Explore drug efficacy
  • Called a therapeutic exploratory trial or proof of concept trial

Phase 3
  • Design: Double-blinded RCT 
  • Purpose: 
    • Find the optimal drug dose
    • Confirm efficacy
    • Safety is priority
  • Called a therapeutic confirmatory trial 
  • Called multi-site trial (done on a heterogeneous population)
  • Drugs get market approval

Phase 4
  • Design: Open-label
  • Purpose: 
    • Find hidden/missed/rare adverse effects. 
    • Evaluate compliance: long-term side effects
    • Drug interactions
    • Food interactions
  • Called post-marketing surveillance
